title: Stop trying https if http is unavailable
content:
My cable modem presents a web interface on 192.168.100.1.

If I'm having internet connection issues, I go to http://192.168.100.1 to look at the log and see what's going on.

If the modem is not responding, Firefox pulls a stupid and checks https://192.168.100.1.

The problem is that it changes the URL bar, so now I can't hit F5 or anything; nor can I just edit out the "s" because of the URL bar autocompleter's habit of changing what you typed as soon as you press enter; I have to delete the entire URL and re-enter http://192.168.100.1.

How do I disable the silly "try HTTPS instead" feature when I explicitly typed "http://"?
creator: petteyg359

title: HUGE PROBLEM! No access to my verification email.
content: Today I deleted a folder containing firefox data without knowing it while making space for a windows update. Sadly firefox contains almost all password data - usually a 24 random character string. I tried to sync my device with the online account for which I know the password. BUT my email account is protected by a string known only by firefox. I can log in to my firefox account to the moment until the second verification step. Unfortunately I can't retrive my email nor reset the password for the account, which itself is a huge hub for other online accounts. If I can not access the firefox sync account I will have a lots of trouble. Is there any possibility to skip the second verification step? Or are all my passwords and accounts lost?

title: Account sync for bookmarks
content:
Hello,

I just switched to MacOS Big Sur, and while doing so, I decided to do a clean install. Before doing so, I synced my Firefox accountt, wanting to save all my bookmarks and favorites, etc. Now when I signed in to Firefox after the installation, my data is nowhere to be found, and it seems like the current, clean Firefox with no bookmarks etc. has been synced to my Firefox account. Is there a way to restore my data from a previous sync file? I have a lot of data I need for my projects saved up.

Thank you.

title: Cookie selection problem
content: If I, for example use Google as search engine, it always requires me to accept cookies. Then if I have accepted the cookies and go to one of the found pages, read it and go back to the search, Firefox tries to load the same popup window again, but fails. When I open a new tab and reenter the search phrase, the same window for accepting cookies appears. I think this problems have appeared after the latest update to version 82.0.3; not sure if I have changes some preference. My compter is an old MacBookPro with OS 10.13.6. In previous versions, I have been asked now and then to accept google's privacy rules. The similar problems appears for other sites, for example sanoma.com, where I have chosen to accept only the necessary cookies, not third party, analytics, etc. When I open a link and go back, the same question appears again, but for these sites it does not hang up, as in the google case. I mostly use private browsing window, and have better privacy and similar extensions activated.
creator: lussej

title: SSL-Site constant Problem with GeoTrust-Certificate
content:
We run our own servers sonce long using ssl resp. https.

Example : https://ncn.ncenter-cert.com:56000/ish/ as a test site

The certificates (cert + intermediate cert) are correct and origin from GeoTrust USA.

Other Browsers (Google etc.) don't have a problem. But Firefox for windows desktop claims "weak encryption" and the new Firefox for Android refuses to open the page !

I noticed also after restoring it, if you right click inside Firefox, it fixes itself and also when you focus on another window.

I attached a GIF.
creator: chris--

title: Firefox Container blocking Facebook.com web pages?
content: I installed Firefox Facebook container, thinking I could at last feel safe signing up and using Facebook. So I went to the public Facebook.com pages about privacy to examine the latest in their privacy settings, no login required of course. However I was stopped repeatedly by the following error message: Your Request Couldn't be Processed There was a problem with this request. We're working on getting it fixed as soon as we can. I then pasted the same Facebook.com web address into Edge and had no problems viewing facebook.com pages open to the public. Again, I am not trying to sign in and do not have an active Facebook account. Does Firefox management know if Facebook is sabotaging Facebook Container either deliberately or by neglect, or if Facebook is actually working on allowing the use of Facebook Container on Firefox while using Facebook.com pages?
creator: Quenchoo

title: Disable Ctrl + Shift + Q
content:
Is there some way to disable Ctrl + Shift + Q without installing 3rd party software? Most of the key mapping extensions contain security warnings.

I find myself constantly frustrated that a "destructive" action like quit has been put so closely beside a productive option like cycle back a tab. The combination of having Ctrl + Shift + Q beside Ctrl + Shift + Tab is quite obnoxious on a QWERTY keyboard. I would like to try map this to something that makes more sense like Ctrl + Shift + E or Ctrl + Alt + Q.

I'm running Firefox 82.0.3.

title: Malware Auto Download with Capital One Download URL
content:
I happened on a page: https://capitaloneshopping.com/join-capital-one-shopping?utm_source=Meerkat&utm_campaign=107592707702&utm_term=472928718855&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI0Ij6h5iD7QIVgi0MCh2TLgrJEAEYASAAEgJALvD_BwE

And it immediately began "downloading an app" and I quit the page before it could get far, but, obviously, that doesn't mean it stopped. However, now Firefox is acting a little wiggy, and I'm concerned it might have downloaded something that's affecting the browser. Was trying to read about "capital one shopping malware," and pages wouldn't open when any links on the search results were clicked, etc.

Is this a known issue? Resolutions offered?
